Items.Definition: Able to be maintained at a certain rate or level without causing damage to the environment or resources.
Items.Example: Many governments are investing in sustainable energy sources to reduce pollution.

Items.Definition: To make something less severe, serious, or harmful.
Items.Example: Planting more trees can help mitigate the effects of climate change.

Items.Definition: A noticeable and often unfair difference between people or groups.
Items.Example: There is still a significant disparity in income between rural and urban areas.

Items.Definition: The subjects and content that are studied in a particular course or at a school or university.
Items.Example: Many schools are updating their curriculum to include more digital skills.

Items.Definition: The introduction of new ideas, methods, or devices.
Items.Example: Innovation in technology has transformed the way people communicate.

Items.Definition: The basic systems and services, such as transport and power supplies, that a country or organization uses to work effectively.
Items.Example: Improved transport infrastructure can boost regional economic growth.

Items.Definition: The gap between people who have access to modern information and communication technology and those who do not.
Items.Example: The digital divide makes it difficult for some students to study online.

Items.Definition: Money that you pay to take classes, especially at a college or university.
Items.Example: Rising tuition fees have made higher education less accessible for some families.

Items.Definition: The process by which more and more people leave the countryside to live in cities.
Items.Example: Rapid urbanization often leads to overcrowded housing and traffic congestion.

Items.Definition: Relating to energy that is produced from resources that cannot be used up, such as wind or sunlight.
Items.Example: Solar panels are a common way to use renewable energy.
